description: From Middle English assemblen, from Old French assembler (“to assemble”), from Medieval Latin assimulāre (“to bring together”), from ad- +‎ simulō (“copy, imitate”), from similis (“like, similar”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *sem- (“together, one”). Doublet of assimilate.

verbs.description: assemble (third-person singular simple present assembles, present participle assembling, simple past and past participle assembled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To gather as a group.
examples: The parents assembled in the school hall.

entries.meaning: (computing) To translate from assembly language to machine code.
